# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Here is the function `wrap_string` that wraps the input text to a maximum width specified by `text_width`:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    wrapped = ""
    current_line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) <= text_width
            current_line *= " " * word
        else
            wrapped *= rstrip(current_line) * "\n"
            current_line = word
        end
    end
    wrapped *= rstrip(current_line)
    return wrapped
end
```

Here's an example usage:

```julia
text = "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text)
println(wrapped_text)
```

This will output:

```
The quick
brown fox
jumps over
the lazy
dog.
```

The function `wrap_string` takes an `AbstractString` as input and an optional `text_width` parameter, which defaults to 10. It first splits the input text into a vector of words using `split(text)`. Then, it iterates over the words, building up a `current_line` string. Whenever adding the next word would exceed the `text_width`, it appends the current line to the `wrapped` string, and starts a new line with the current word.

Finally, it appends the last line to the `wrapped` string and returns the fully wrapped text.

The `rstrip(current_line)` is used to remove any trailing whitespace from the last line.
